titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Josiah C. McCracken Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:05

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, and collected material document the work of a distinguished medical missionary and educator in China and provide information about graduates of the Medical Department of St. John's University, Shanghai. Josiah Calvin McCracken was a medical missionary and educator in China from 1906 to 1948. Sent out by the Christian Association of the University of Pennsylvania, he headed the medical department at Canton Christian College from 1907 to 1912, and at St. John's University in Shanghai from 1914-1942

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Helen McCracken Fulcher and Martha McCracken.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Josiah C. McCracken Papers (RG 113), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical

chronitem.event: Born in Lincoln County, Tennessee; grew up in Kansas
Attended Cooper College, which became Sterling College, Sterling, KS
Attended University of Pennsylvania Medical School; athletic star in football and track
Medical intern at Pennsylvania Hospital, Philadelphia
Visited China to evaluate need for medical work there for Christian Association of University of Pennsylvania
Married Helen Newpher, who became the mother of their eight children.
Developed the University Medical School at Canton Christian College, serving under the Christian Association of the University of Pennsylvania
On furlough in U.S.; daughter Mary Elizabeth paralyzed by polio, but was later able to go to medical school and become a pediatrician in China.

Dean of the Medical School of St. John's University, associated with the University of Pennsylvania; Professor of Surgery and chief surgeon at St. Luke's Hospital; physician to Shanghai American School.
Received honorary Doctor of Science degree from University of Pennsylvania
Head of American Red Cross Hospital for Refugees, Shanghai
Repatriated on the exchange ship Gripsholm
Staff surgeon at hospital in Pennsylvania
Returned to Shanghai to reestablished Medical School at St. John's.

Returned to U.S.; retired from active professional duties but remained active in church-related activities. Provided numerous letters of reference for St. John's Medical School graduates seeking employment in the U.S.

bioghist.p: Additional biographical information available in Mission to Shanghai; the life of medical service of Josiah Calvin McCracken by Helen McCracken Fulcher.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Biographical Documentation of Series I includes articles and clippings about McCracken, memorabilia, and material compiled by his daughter Helen McCracken Fulcher. The Correspondence of Series II includes family correspondence, circular letters describing McCracken's work in China, and a valuable of collection of correspondence and documents relating to the graduates of the Medical Department of St. John's University in Shanghai. The Writings and Collected Material of Series III include articles and speeches by McCracken, other articles about China, and documentation related to the University of Pennsylvania Medical School at St. John's University. Series IV includes photographs of McCracken, his students and their families, the staff of the Medical School in Canton, and medical cases.

did.unittitle: Biographical material re. the McCracken children
Looseleaf notebook: "The Story of Dr. Josiah Calvin McCracken, 1874-1962: The McCrackens of Shanghai, A Family Portrait" by Helen McCracken Fulcher (244 mimeographed typescript pages)
Corres. with United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia
Re. graduates of St. John's Medical School
List of graduates of Medical Department of St. John's University
'The Work of the Medical School in China" (University of Pennsylvania Medical School in Canton)
"What the University of Pennsylvania is Doing for Medical Education in South China"
Book review of Peking Diary by Derk Bodde
"How I Became a Christian" by Shao Chang Lee
Speech by Mr. Mansfield Freeman of United Service to China
Circular letter of Charles and Leila Boynton, Shanghai
"Things You Don't Read in the Papers"
"Biographical Sketches St. John's University (Shanghai) Medical School Graduates (1943-1952)" and Supplement (1934-1952)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two volumes of biographical sketches compiled by the St. John's University Medical School Alumni Association in North America, 2001

did.unittitle: Documents re. curriculum and evaluation of the Pennsylvania Medical School, medical department of St. John's University
President's Report, University Medical School, Canton
First National Conference of Chinese Churches in America
Statements by Walter H. Judd re. situation in China
Medical cases and dissection of cadaver
Chinese children and families of former students
Scenes in China: refugees, aftermath of Japanese bombing, etc.
